comments:
Eclipse 3.3RC1 I20070517-1700:

A problem with P4WSAD plug-in by Perforce at startup prevents Eclipse from coming up. It's a well known fact that P4WSAD plug-in is buggy, but it should not prevent the platform from starting. Here is the error log:

!SESSION 2007-06-04 10:53:34.574 -----------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=I20070517-1700
java.version=1.6.0_01
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=gtk, NL=en_US
Framework arguments:  -startup /opt/eclipse3.3RC1/plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.0.0.v20070516.jar
Command-line arguments:  -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86 -startup /opt/eclipse3.3RC1/plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.0.0.v20070516.jar

!MESSAGE The workspace exited with unsaved changes in the previous session; refreshing workspace to recover changes.

"org.eclipse.swt.SWTException"= SWTException  (id=41)   
    cause= SWTException  (id=41)   
    code= 22   
    detailMessage= "Invalid thread access"   
    stackTrace= null   
    throwable= null   

It is very bad that static initialization of PreferenceConverter can only happen on the UI thread. Promoting to critical.

> It is very bad that static initialization of PreferenceConverter can only
> happen on the UI thread. Promoting to critical.

No, JFace is a UI framework. Unless otherwise stated, everything in JFace may access the UI thread. In the case of PreferenceConverter, it even explicitly states that it requires access to the display:

 * Note: touching this class has the side effect of creating a display (static initializer).

This is a bug in the perforce plugin.

Created an attachment (id=73796)
Proposed fix

Please review and apply.
Adding Tod to CC for comment on JFace.

All UI plug-ins follow the same contract as SWT as they are SWT based - they need to run on the UI thread.

PreferenceConverter may be in JFace but it's implementation does not imply that JFace can be used off of the UI Thread.

Likely that we were being extra careful when we did it. Sometimes you can get away with it if you are calling SWT API that does not need a Thread check and so it would work in those cases but not in the others where SWT requires the UI thread.

Being  more defensive in our implementation should not be used to indicate intented behaviour - only the API makes promises.

(In reply to comment #10)
> Likely that we were being extra careful when we did it.
What is wrong with adding little more extra carefulness and applying the proposed patch?
It is indeed a P4WSAD plug-in's problem.

Additional notes for the record: Here's how to faithfully reproduce this plugin compatibility error. (Steps 1,2,3 probably needs an eclipse restart between them)

1. Install P4WSAD plugin from http://www.perforce.com/downloads/http/p4-wsad/install/
version 2006.2.4136 contains the bug despite the release notes which state: "#24185 Eclipse crashed on startup after a system crash. This has been fixed."

2. Share a project via the perforce plugin

3. Open a file for edit, or start a new file and type at least 100 characters. This is to get the workspace saver to create the snapshot files. Keep making edits until you have .snap files in your workspace.

4. Kill eclipse with kill -9 or ctrl-C

5. Try to start eclipse. When it tries to recover the workspace, the legacy initializeDefaultPreferences method will be called on the perforce ui plugin from a Worker pool thread instead of main causing the errors and launch failure.

See also: bug 197070
